newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian crude firmer, but diffs struggle on upside.
newsitem.headline: Asian crude firmer, but diffs struggle on upside.

text.p: Asian crude prices were slightly higher on Monday but with few signs emerging that differentials were getting any firmer.
Oman slipped to MPM -21/-23 as a Japanese trader sold a cargo of the crude to a U.S. major. The deal surpassed the previous discount by at least one cent.
However, traders said they felt Oman was bottoming out for the time being.
They said the market was likely to adopt a holding pattern until the result of the Bangchak June buying tender emerged. The tender closes Monday and is valid until late Tuesday.
Several majors and traders still had Oman to sell. A few buyers were seen, bidding at a discount of more than 20 cents.
Qatar Marine traded at QGPC -45 cents between a Japanese trader and a U.S. major. The price was largely in line with the market.
But Philippines' refiner Petron purchased a Qatar Marine from a buy tender at Dubai quotes +68 cents from a French major, giving more leeway to hedge exposure to official selling prices.
The Indian oil tender result helped consoliate a slight backwardation for the Dubai market, swinging from contango for most of last week.
The IOC took three Dubai cargoes, indicating that most June Dubai was now placed, unless a continued rise in the Dubai spreads sparked a buyer to sell Dubai back out into the market.

June/July Dubai was assessed at +3/+10 cents and traders said if holders of Dubai -- who had bought as low as -10 cents last week -- were offered +10 cents, they might be tempted to lock in the profit.
Minas traded in line with the recent market, with a Japanese trader selling 200,000 barrels of May barrels to a Japanese refinery at ICP +10/+15 cents.
